G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Massachusetts law entrusts Probate and Family Courts with the discretionary authority to modify custody orders where there has been a **"material and substantial change in circumstances"** and where modification is in the **"best interests of the child."**

_Bouchard v. Bouchard_, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts law entrusts Probate and Family Courts with the discretionary authority to modify custody orders where there has been a **"material and substantial change in circumstances"** and where modification is in the **"best interests of the child."**
_Bouchard v. Bouchard_, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the substantive standard for awarding custody (the welfare or best interests of the child) and criticizes the trial judge for not applying those criteria. It does not address modification of an existing custody order, nor does it mention the separate requirement of a “material and substantial change in circumstances.” Therefore, it supports only the best‑interests component, not the full proposition as stated.
_Bouchard v. Bouchard_, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

_Raymond v. Raymond_, 165 Mass. 573 (189.proposition: The best interests of the minor children remain the paramount concern in custody disputes.

_Foley v. Foley_, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 221,.proposition: The best interests of the minor children remain the paramount concern in custody disputes.
_Foley v. Foley_, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 221,.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt deals with property division, expert valuation testimony, alleged judicial bias, and counsel fees in a divorce proceeding, not with the legal standard governing child custody determinations. There is no discussion of custody or any statement that the best interests of the minor children are the paramount concern in custody disputes. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the claimed best‑interests proposition.
_Foley v. Foley_, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 221,.relevant_excerpt: It does not appear that the husband’s appeal challenges either the granting of the divorce or the alimony and child support portions of the order, including those concerning medical insurance. See Yanolis v. Yanolis, 402 Mass. 470, 472-474 (1988).

_Harris v. Harris_, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 93.proposition: Courts must consider whether one parent is interfering with the children’s relationship with the other parent when determining the best interest of the child.
_Harris v. Harris_, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 93.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with modification of an alimony judgment based on a material change of financial circumstances, particularly the wife's inheritance. It does not discuss child custody standards, best interests of the child, or parental interference with the children’s relationship with the other parent. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition regarding courts’ consideration of interference with parent-child relationships in best-interest determinations.
_Harris v. Harris_, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 93.relevant_excerpt: "In order for a petitioner to be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, he or she must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Schuler v. Schuler, supra at 368. The change may be in the needs or the resources, or both, of the parties. Pagar v. Pagar, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 1,2 (1980)."

_Rolde v. Rolde_, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: Shared legal custody requires that parents communicate effectively and make joint decisions in the children’s interests. Where such cooperation is lacking, sole legal custody may be appropriate.
_Rolde v. Rolde_, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses when joint/shared custody is appropriate and expressly states that joint custody requires parents to be able to agree on basic child-rearing issues, respect each other as parents, and work together on major decisions. It affirms that where, as in this case, there is severe antagonism and fundamental disagreement about child rearing, joint custody is inappropriate and sole custody is warranted in the children’s best interests. This aligns closely with the claimed proposition.
_Rolde v. Rolde_, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests. … [I]n order to be effective ‘joint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions….’”

_Doe v. Doe_, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (198.proposition: Shared legal custody requires that parents communicate effectively and make joint decisions in the children’s interests. Where such cooperation is lacking, sole legal custody may be appropriate.
_Doe v. Doe_, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly addresses when joint (shared) legal custody is appropriate in the face of parental conflict, relying on Rolde and reciting that for joint custody to work, both parents must be able to agree on basic childrearing issues and want to cooperate in making decisions. The court then distinguishes this case on the facts, finding that although the parents have interpersonal conflict and communication problems, these do not involve disagreements over the child’s care, custody, and upbringing. Thus, the case affirms the underlying principle that lack of such cooperative decision‑making can make joint custody inappropriate, even though it finds joint custody proper here.
_Doe v. Doe_, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (198.relevant_excerpt: “In contending that the conflict between the parties precludes an award of joint custody, the husband relies upon Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981), where the court agreed with the trial judge’s observation that ‘in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually “to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.”’ … We think that Rolde is inapplicable on these facts and that the probate judge was justified in concluding that any existing conflict between the parties is not of the type which would render the joint legal and physical custody award inappropriate for David.”}

_Hunter v. Rose_, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..proposition: In _Hunter v. Rose_, 463 Mass. 488 (2012), the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court recognized that stability and reduced conflict are crucial to children’s emotional health and development.
_Hunter v. Rose_, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..support_reasoning: The opinion’s custody analysis expressly identifies stability, reduced conflict, and protection from alienating behavior as central components of the “best interests of the child,” with a particular focus on the child’s emotional and psychological well‑being. The SJC discusses how disrupted attachments, instability, and parental alienation can cause long-term emotional harm, and it favors the parent who can provide a more stable environment and support the child’s relationship with both parents. This aligns with the proposition that the court recognized stability and reduced conflict as crucial to children’s emotional health and development.
_Hunter v. Rose_, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance between parents, ‘it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.’… [T]he judge also assessed the stability each parent offered Jill….”

_Smith v. McDonald_, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Excessive parental conflict and disparagement in front of children have been found to justify modifications to custody arrangements.
_Smith v. McDonald_, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The opinion is about relocation and statutory interpretation under the paternity statute for a nonmarital child. It does not address excessive parental conflict, disparagement in front of children, or modification of custody on that basis. The discussion concerns the mother’s right to relocate as sole legal parent and the judge’s lack of authority to order her return, not parental conflict as a ground for modifying custody arrangements.
_Smith v. McDonald_, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: "The paternity statute further provides that ‘the mother shall continue to have custody after an adjudication of paternity or voluntary acknowledgment of parentage’ (emphasis added) unless and until a court orders otherwise. G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (b)."

_Rosenberg v. Merida_, 428 Mass. 182 (19.proposition: That the Court order both parties to refrain from making disparaging comments about the other parent in the presence of the children, pursuant to _Rosenberg v. Merida_, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).
_Rosenberg v. Merida_, 428 Mass. 182 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns child support calculations involving Social Security disability dependency benefits, attachment of assets, and a modification of legal custody. It does not address, discuss, or order any restrictions on either parent making disparaging comments about the other in the presence of the children. Therefore, Rosenberg v. Merida does not provide authority for a non-disparagement order between parents.
_Rosenberg v. Merida_, 428 Mass. 182 (19.relevant_excerpt: The judgment stripped the *191plaintiff of shared legal custody with the defendant of their minor child and awarded sole legal custody to the defendant. General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding “that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].” … The only finding contained in the modification judgment is that “the parties are unable to communicate with one another.”
